title: Dashboard definitions
content:
From the dashboard definition administration module in Service Management (Administration > Master Data > Dashboard Definitions), authorized users can create, view, and manage dashboard definition records. For your convenience, the system offers a set of out-of-the-box dashboard definitions intended for different user roles. For example, the Incident overview dashboard definition is for Incident Manager and Asset overview for Asset Manager. 

Agent users can view these dashboard definitions from their dashboard home page. Each agent user has a default dashboard, which is the initial dashboard that loads for the user after login. The default dashboard can be specified by the user (from the user profile), by the tenant admin, or by the system (listed from the highest to lowest priority). For information about how users work with dashboards from their dashboard home page, see Overview of dashboards.

Dashboard definition administration

A tenant admin can perform the following administration tasks for dashboard definitions.

Assign dashboard role permissions

A dashboard has one of the following access levels:

  • Private: visible only to the agent user who creates it. 
  • Public: visible to all agent users.
  • Group: visible only to one or more specified groups of users.

As a best practice, a tenant admin can create different roles and assign them to appropriate users. The following table describes the role permissions required to view, create, and update dashboard definitions. Pay attention to the following:

  • To enable menu visibility for Dashboard Definitions, you need to select the Visible checkbox for Dashboard Definitions in the Administration menu visibility section on the Role form.
  • The Create public dashboards permission and Create group dashboards permission are in the Reports & Views section on the Role form.
Operation Permissions
View dashboards on the dashboard home page

None.

The audience setting of a dashboard controls who can view it. 

A user needs no dashboard role permissions to view the following active dashboards from their dashboard home page:

  • All public dashboards
  • All group dashboards for which the user is a member of the specified group and all group dashboards created by the user
  • All dashboards created by the user

Note: Saving a new copy as a private dashboard from the dashboard home page requires the "Create" and "View" permissions for Dashboard Definition, while editing a private dashboard requires the "Update" and "View" permissions.
Create and update private dashboards
  • Create/View/Update/Delete permissions for the Dashboard Definition record type
  • Menu visibility for Dashboard Definitions
Create and update public dashboards
  • Create/View/Update/Delete permissions for the Dashboard Definition record type
  • Create public dashboards permission
  • Menu visibility for Dashboard Definitions
Create and update group dashboards
  • Create/View/Update/Delete permissions for the Dashboard Definition record type
  • Create group dashboards  permission
  • Menu visibility for Dashboard Definitions
Set a system default dashboard
  • Update and Admin permissions for the Dashboard Definition record type
  • Menu visibility for Dashboard Definitions

Configure record level access control

The dashboard role permissions control whether an agent user can view, create, or update definition records. A tenant admin can further configure access control to narrow down the Dashboard Definition records that an agent user can view and manage from Administration > Master Data > Dashboard Definitions. For details, see Record level access control.

Add the system default dashboard field to the form

By default, the System default dashboard field isn't available on the dashboard definition form. A tenant admin can add this field to the form so that users can identify a system default dashboard:

  1. Navigate to Administration > Configuration > Studio.
  2. Open the Dashboard Definition record type. The Full DashboardDefinition form opens. 
  3. Click Add field, and then select the System default dashboard field. 
  4. Click Done and then Save.

Work with dashboard definitions

Agent users can work with dashboard definitions as follows.

Create a dashboard definition

You can also use the Duplicate button in an existing dashboard definition to create another. Note that this feature doesn't copy the following data to the new record: Discussions, Owner, Owning group, and Access level (which is set to Private in the new record). 
  1. From the main menu, navigate to Administration > Master Data > Dashboard Definitions.
  2. Click New.
  3. Enter a name and a display label. 
  4. Select an access level, to control what users are allowed to view this dashboard on their Dashboard home page:
    • Private: a private dashboard definition for yourself.
    • Group: a dashboard definition to share with one or more groups of users. If you select Group, click Add in the Audience section to add one or more groups. 
      If no groups are selected in the Audience section, only the dashboard's creator and the tenant admin can view the dashboard on the homepage.
    • Public: a public dashboard definition to share with all users.
  5. Complete other optional fields.
  6. Click Save.

Edit a dashboard definition

  • You can't update the content of a group or public dashboard definition that's in Active state. To update the content, move the record to the Draft state first.  
  • You can't update the Name field of an out-of-the-box dashboard definition.
  1. Open the dashboard definition from the list.
  2. Update the fields as needed on the General tab.
  3. Update the content:
    If this is an out-of-the-box dashboard definition, you can click Reset content to restore the out-of-the-box content. 
    1. Click the Content tab, and then click Click to add.
    2. Select an existing report from the report list and then click Add to add the report. Or, click New to create a new report and then click Save.
    3. Repeat the steps to add more reports to the dashboard definition. Note that you can add up to 50 reports to a dashboard definition.
    4. To remove unwanted reports, select a report and then click the More icon > Remove widget. 
  4. Add comments in either way:
    • Click the Comments button, add comments, and then click Add and Save Record.
    • Click the Discussions tab, enter comments, and then click Add and Save. 
  5. Click Save. 

Activate the dashboard definition

A newly created dashboard definition is in Draft state. If you believe it's ready for use, activate it so that it's available to authorized users:

  1. Click the Workflow tab of the dashboard definition.
  2. Click Active, and then click the Save button that appears.

To deactivate the dashboard definition, on the Workflow tab, click Inactive and then Save. The record becomes inactive.

To reactivate the dashboard definition, click Draft to move it to Draft state, make necessary edits, and then click Active.

Delete a dashboard definition

  • You can't delete out-of-the-box dashboard definitions or a system default dashboard definition. 
  • If you delete a dashboard definition that's set as a user's default dashboard, the system loads the system default dashboard or the System Dashboard Definition dashboard for the user.
  1. Select the dashboard definition from the list.
  2. Click Delete, and confirm the deletion. 

Specify a default dashboard for users

You can set a default dashboard in a user's Person record, and set a system default dashboard (which will act as the default dashboard for users who have no default dashboard configured in their Person record). 

Set a system default dashboard

  • You must have the required dashboard role permissions to perform this task. See the Assign dashboard role permissions section. 
  • The system can have no more than one system default dashboard. If the system has already one, the new one you set will take the place of the old one. 
  • You can't delete a system default dashboard. 
  • If there's no system default dashboard specified, the system uses an out-of-box dashboard named System Dashboard Definition instead for users who have no default dashboard assigned. 

To set a system default dashboard:

  1. Open a public dashboard definition that is in Active state from Administration > Master Data > Dashboard Definitions. 
  2. Click Set as system default. A dialog opens, indicating that you can have only one system default dashboard and the current record will take the place of the existing one if there's already one. 
    This button is active only in public dashboard definitions that are in Active state. Additionally, if you don't have the Admin permission for the Dashboard Definition record type, you won't be able to see this button. 
  3. Click Yes to continue. The screen displays a message indicating that you have set the system default dashboard successfully. If your tenant admin has added the System default dashboard field to the dashboard definition form from Studio, you can see that the System default dashboard check box in the current record is checked. By default, this check box is not available on the form. 

To cancel a system default dashboard:

  1. Open the dashboard definition record.
  2. Clear the System default dashboard check box. 
  3. Save the record. 

Specify a default dashboard in Person records


To perform this task, you must be either a tenant admin or a user who has permission to update Person records and view dashboard definitions. 

To specify a default dashboard for a user:

  1. Go to Administration > People.
  2. Open the Person record of the user. 
  3. In the Default dashboard field, select a dashboard from the list. Note that the list displays only dashboard definitions that the current person is authorized to access. 
  4. Click Save. 
Agent users can also change their default dashboard from their user profile (see Set your default dashboard). Their user profile setting will overwrite the setting in their Person record.
